Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Optimization and Parameterization for Multiscale Cardiovascular Flow Simulations Using High Performance Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
For the past century, advances in cardiovascular surgery have mainly come about through a `trial and error' approach, using surgeon experience, and evaluation of patient outcomes to judge success. On the other hand, the engineering field has developed sophisticated tools for computational simulation and optimization that have now become commonplace in the the design process. Similar tools could greatly benefit the medical field by offering the means to systematically test new surgical designs at no risk to the patient, and to customize designs for individual patients. While great strides have been made in developing cardiovascular simulation methods, hurdles remain before ordering a patient-specific simulation is as easy as, for example, ordering a chest x-ray. Major roadblocks to adoption of these methods in the clinic include the current lack of cyberinfrastructure that can achieve clinically relevant time frames, as well as a lack of tools for efficient manipulation and optimization of surgical designs.

The main objective of this project is to pioneer the development of novel and efficient computational methods which can be applied for optimization in surgery and device design, and to demonstrate the use of these tools using high performance computing. Novel cyberinfrastructure will be developed, including new physics-based tools for patient specific geometry parameterization, and expanded optimization and uncertainty quantification methods for use in a parallel environment. This optimization and uncertainty framework will result in a multi-layered parallel computing structure, in which multiple cost function evaluations will be performed simultaneously, each requiring a multi-processor finite element simulation. These unique computational approaches will be applied to three cardiovascular shape optimization applications using high performance computing. In particular, the PI will apply the computational methods and tools to (1) perform customization of designs for surgery to treat children with single ventricle heart defects, (2) quantify hemodynamics in coronary aneurysms caused by Kawasaki disease, and (3) perform robust design to improve coronary artery bypass graft surgery. The PI will also use systematic uncertainty quantification tools to assess the reliability of cardiovascular simulations to improve confidence in results. In the future, this framework will be used to design individual treatments for patients suffering from a wide range of congenital and acquired heart diseases. These tools have potential to impact quality of life for patients, delay the need for a heart transplant, increase exercise tolerance for children with heart defects, and in some cases reduce mortality. The application of optimal design tools will bring a paradigm shift to the medical community by offering the first quantitative and systematic methods for optimizing surgeries and treatment plans at no risk to the patient. These tools will have broader use in a range of engineering applications requiring coupling between optimization and large scale numerical solvers, including turbulence, combustion, fluid structure interaction, and medical device design.

We will lead an integrated interdisciplinary education and outreach plan that will draw high school students, particularly women and minorities, to the field of engineering and computational science. Our education plan will address training needs in a new interdisciplinary area by exposing students to cardiovascular medicine, and doctors to quantitative simulation-based tools. The outreach program, including an after school science program and a booth at the San Diego Science Festival, will draw disadvantaged students to science and engineering by exposing them to emerging research and career options.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this CAREER grant, we developed a suite of computational tools to aid in the manipulation, optimization, and simulation of cardiovascular blood flow and physiology for applications in cardiovascular medicine. While previous research had enabled patient-specific anatomic modeling from medical image data and realistic blood flow simulations, prior methods were note adquate for efficient manipulation and automated optimization of complex surgerical models. As such, manipulations had to be done by hand, and this severely restricted the number of cases that could be tested. To overcome these barriers, we developed methods and software to perform automated cardiovascular surgery optimization, assess uncertainties in simulation predictions, and improve how we handle complex geometries.

 

A major technical contribution was the development of optimization methods that allow for automated manipulation and simulation of cardiovascular surgical geometries, building on optimal design methodology from traditional engineering disciplines in aerospace engineering. A framework for running parallel optimization on high performance computing clusters was developed and shown to enable substantial reductions in overall optimization time. Several aspects of the optimization methodology were explored, including parameter space exploration strategies. The parallel optimization framework was demonstrated on several representative cardiovascular surgical geometries. This framework was implemented inside SimVascular, a leading open source project providing a pipeline from medical image data to anatomic modeling and simulation. Automated scripts were written to perform the steps in the simulation pipeline, and linked with derivative-free optimization methods suitable for expensive function evaluations. In conjunction with this, novel tools were also developed to assimilate clinical data into simulations and to quantify uncertainties on simulation predictions, a key step towards clinical adoption.

 

A significant outcome of this work was the application of our optimization methods to a novel surgical method for children born with single ventricle heart defects, the assisted bidirectional Glenn (ABG). Optimization allowed us to very quickly simulate hundreds of possible operating conditions for the proposed surgery. The ABG surgery has enourmous potential to impact patient care, and could eliminate one of the three stages of surgery. The optimization tools developed in this proposal were crucial to enable efficient exploration of the design space and identification of a best performing cases, which improved our understanding and generated novel designs for further exploration and future clinical translation. Our optimization methods can also be leveraged for a wide range of other parameter estimation and cardiovascular surgery problems.

 

Additionally, we applied our simulation, uncertainty, and geometry manipulation tools to coronary artery disease simulations in two diseases. Clinical data assimilation and uncertainty propagation were performed in models of coronary bypass graft surgery, and alternative surgical designs were tested. In addition, simulations were performed in models of children with Kawasaki disease, and coronary aneurysm geometry was manipulated to assess the impact on hemodynamics and thrombotic risk.

 

The project motivated an array of educational and scientific outreach activities. A new course on Computational Modeling in the Cardiovascular System was developed, which included project based learning for students using the SimVascular project, integrating research and education. Outreach activities to education the public about our research included workshops for schoolkids through the Johns Hopkins Center for Talented Youth and visits to the Beechwood School in East Palo Alto.
